page.title: 03SHERIFF HUTTON ECOLOGY
page.content: With the plain of York to the south and the Howardian Hills to the north, this area consists of undulating farm lands plus a small amount of park land and woods.Due to alterations of farming practice the natural history has changed-hedges and old oaks have been cut down in the last ten years.Flaura and fauna are now of the more common type,in odd places rarer flowers-cowslips and yellow rattle are found.Birds have adopted a new habitat in the well tended village gardens but bats and owls still remain around the village. Conservation of the park land oaks was ignored by one owner resulting in great change when these old trees were felled in 1979.25 acres were planted under a dedicated woodland scheme in 1977,this is situated between the pond and park house.
